Parents, we know that concerns about COVID-19 may have kept you away from your doctor's office the past few months. But it's important to keep in mind that there are other very serious diseases that you can protect your children from by making sure they are up to date on immunizations.

The Klickitat County Health Department is holding immunization clinics in White Salmon on August 20 and Goldendale on August 19. Flyers are below. We encourage you to take advantage of this opportunity to get the immunizations done.

The state has made some changes in immunization requirements. Among them, you must provide medically-verified immunization records to the school before your child can attend, and some exemptions can no longer be claimed.

Read more on the State Health Department webpage at www.doh.wa.gov/YouandYourFamily/Immunization/SchoolandChildCare/RuleChanges

Heads up! Parents, we need your input in the next five days to help shape our re-opening plan. That plan is coming along well, but one thing we have realized is that opening with all kids on campus five days a week is probably NOT do-able.

Safety requirements, including distancing rules, are the main reason we are looking at a hybrid on-site/remote learning option.

You can read more on our webpage, but we ESPECIALLY need your input. The number of kids who will be on campus is the biggest factor in our plan.

To let us know what you have in mind for your child this school year, click here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdAtZPciXc-Bb-FCuZCRDDLkuLUIeJ-u6vQT9g5hSD3DrcSKw/viewform.

Heads up! Parents, we need your input in the next five days to help shape our re-opening plan. That plan is coming along well, but one thing we have realized is that opening with all kids on campus five days a week is probably NOT do-able.

Safety requirements, including distancing rules, are the main reason we are looking at a hybrid on-site/remote learning option.

You can read more on our webpage, but we ESPECIALLY need your input. The number of kids who will be on campus is the biggest factor in our plan.

To let us know what you have in mind for your child this school year, click here: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSdAtZPciXc-Bb-FCuZCRDDLkuLUIeJ-u6vQT9g5hSD3DrcSKw/viewform.

Here's a sweet idea from retired first-grade teacher Nancy Moon. You've probably seen the photos: Someone puts a teddy bear or other stuffed animal in their window, in a tree, on their porch... anywhere really.

Kids on walks or drives through the neighborhood with their families try to find as many as they can. It‚Äôs like a scavenger hunt. And, being the age of social media, they take a photo and share it! If you decide to do this, we'd love to see your photos. Tag us @lyleschools, or send in a direct message and we'll share it!

This game is being played in countries around the world, from Australia to Japan to the United States.

Nancy - and the rest of us - would love to see everyone participate. Put a bear somewhere it can be see from the street.

If you're a parent or caregiver for little ones, take them on a walk or drive. To add to the fun, read the book, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre Going on a Bear Hunt‚Äù by Michael Rosen and Helen Oxenbury with them before you go out.

If you can't find the book online to read to your child, here's a fun video version!

post_text: Parents, as you've probably heard, Governor Jay Inslee and State Superintendent of Public Instruction Chris Reykdal announced yesterday that regular, on-site school will not resume this school year. By physically distancing ourselves now, we are helping to slow the spread of this terrible virus. And we're helping ensure that when we do return to school, the chance of an outbreak will be far less. Learning can and will go on, with you as our partners. Please read the letter from Superintendent Ann Varkados and Principal Lori Smith here or on our webpage, www.lyleschools.org. If you find yourself struggling with the emotional or economic impact of the extended stay-at-home order, please reach out to us. Email support@lyleschools.org.

Why not take time during the long school closure to teach your kids a dying art? Letter writing! Do you remember how fun it was to find a hand-written letter in your mailbox? Residents of nursing homes sure do, and we bet they would love to hear from someone while they are isolated from their families and friends.

That someone could be your child, or you and your child together. Here's a recent request from a nursing home in Vancouver. But you could pick any nursing home, like those in The Dalles or Hood River, and address it to "Any Resident."

If you want to send us a photo of the letter you plan to send, we would love to share it with the community. C'mon people, let's get those envelopes and stamps out (you can use a rag or sponge to dab water on the adhesive areas) and start writing!

Need some ideas for what to say? Here are a few:
My name is ....
I am XX years old.
My favorite food is...
My best subject in school is...
My best friend is....
People say I ....
If I could go anywhere or do anything, it would be ...
When I'm 99 years old, I will be ....

post_text: We're thinking ahead to football, and the fact that next year, Lyle Schools will play in an Oregon league. We've been granted permission from both the WIAA and the OSAA to switch to the northeast Oregon Big Sky League. That means our students will play all sports in Oregon including playoff and championship games. The league is the home of Dufur, Sherman County, South Wasco County, Arlington and several others. The primary reason for the switch? Coaches did a comparison of distances traveled the past 2-3 years as part of the WIAA, and anticipated travel distances as part of the Big Sky League, and found considerable savings for our school districts. It will save money and wear and tear on the buses (not to mention the players and coaches)!

We want to thank Wishram Superintendent/Principal Mike Roberts and Wishram High School Junior Robbie for taking time out of their day yesterday to come to Lyle School. They spent time with our middle school and high school students, sharing the expectations of the Power of ICU program and the reasons for them, and the transformation it has made in the students and culture at Wishram School.

Robbie spoke powerfully about the changes in his personal attitude and academic achievement; once a C and D student, he now has a 3.65 GPA. He also emphasized that he cares about the culture in his school, and wants students to be proud. Superintendent Roberts told the students that the most important thing they could learn in Lyle is "to do what you don't want to do, when you don't want to do it."

Our TADAA students and Prevention Specialist Megan Winn have developed some activities this week to observe Red Ribbon Week and get our students thinking about life choices.

Did you know that research shows that children of parents who talk to their teens regularly about drugs are 42% less likely to use drugs than those who don't? Yet only a quarter of teens report having these conversations. That's why the theme of this year's Red Ribbon Week is "Send a message, stay off drugs!"

You can read more about the school activities on www.lyleschools.org.

Want to know more about Red Ribbon Week?

Red Ribbon Week is an alcohol, tobacco, and other drug and violence prevention awareness campaign observed annually in October in the United States. It began as a tribute to fallen DEA special agent Enrique Camerena in 1985. Schools and organizations around the US participate in the event every year.

http://redribbon.org/about/

A safety reminder for those of you who drop off students in the morning or pick up in the afternoon. We ask you to follow the one-way, clockwise traffic pattern before the start of school and at dismissal time.

Simply enter through the upper parking lot, drop off at the upstairs double doors, and then continue on your way by following the road around the school, finally exiting from the bottom parking lot. Please don't turn around to try to exit west-bound from the upper parking lot.

If you choose to walk your student to class, please use the upper level parking area and doors when dropping off. Kindergarten and prekindergarten parents who pick up in the afternoon: your child's teacher will walk the students outside to meet you near the downstairs double doors.

One more thing: as you come around the building, if buses are stopped in the lower lot to allow students off, please do not pass them. Remain in line behind the bus until it moves. This will typically take just a couple of minutes.

ü•≥ Woohoo! We're counting down the days until school starts! Registration is coming up Monday - Thursday, Aug 12-15, here at the high school. If your child is in grades K-12 and is NEW to the district, please come by between the hours of 9 a.m. and 3 p.m. If you have a conflict with work or another issue that makes it hard to get here during those hours/days, give us a call at 509-365-2211.

Bring a birth certificate and immunization records and, if your child is in high school, a copy of his or her transcripts if you can get them. If you don't have the requested documents, come anyway and we'll work together with you to request them.

Again, kids who attended school here last year do not need to register, but we do need returning students in grades 6-12 to come and pick your classes, get your schedules and find a locker!

The school year calendar can be downloaded and printed from our website, too - go to https://www.lyleschools.org/Page/2773.

post_text: If your child is planning on participating in extracurricular sports, we ask you get them a physical at least every other year (preferably once a year). Fortunately, you can get free health screenings at Northshore Medical Group (near the Hood River Bridge) on Aug. 1 from 6 - 8 p.m. Skyline Hospital's PT & Sports Medicine staff will be on hand to provide the screenings - no appointment needed. To get in and out more quickly, download and complete the needed form before you go. It's available at https://skylinehospital.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/washington-physical-form-2017.pdf.

An excellent if icky lesson on hand-washing!
